verses.text: Whoever touches pitch will be defiled, and whoever associates with the arrogant will become like them.
verses.comment: This proverb highlights the spiritual danger of corrupting influences, echoing the broader biblical principle that we are shaped by our companions. See also 1 Cor. 15:33, where Paul warns about bad company.

verses.text: Do not lift a burden too heavy for you, nor associate with one stronger and richer than you. What fellowship can the clay pot have with the iron pot? The clay pot will be struck and broken.
verses.comment: The imagery of clay and iron emphasizes our human need for humility and prudence. Ecclesiastes warns similarly against chasing influence among the powerful.

verses.text: The rich man does wrong, and he acts with arrogance; the poor man is wronged, and begs for mercy.
verses.comment: A warning about injustice and the behavior of the rich toward the poor, echoed by the prophets' condemnation of oppression. The justice of God will ultimately triumph (cf. Isa. 10:1-4).

verses.text: If you are useful to him, he will make use of you; but if you are in need, he will abandon you.
verses.comment: The conditional nature of worldly relationships contrasts with the faithful love of God. God's covenant never fails, unlike fickle human alliances.

verses.text: If you have possessions, he will live with you; he will drain you dry, and he will not feel sorry for you.
verses.comment: Warnings against exploitative relationships abound in wisdom literature. The call is towards authentic, self-giving love—a recurring biblical ideal.

verses.text: If he needs you, he will deceive you; he will smile at you and give you hope. He will speak nicely to you and say, 'What do you need?'
verses.comment: The duplicity of worldly people recalls the treachery faced by David (Ps. 55:21). Christ cautioned his followers to be wise as serpents (Matt. 10:16).

verses.text: He will embarrass you with his fine foods, until he has drained you two or three times; and in the end he will ridicule you, and see you abandoned, and shake his head at you.
verses.comment: This is a vivid warning about flattery and false hospitality—wisdom counsels discernment, especially among those seeking to use us for gain.

verses.text: Take care not to be led astray and humiliated when you are enjoying yourself.
verses.comment: Evokes the parable of the Good Samaritan, where those who should show mercy do not. The call to charity is ever-present for disciples.

verses.text: When an influential person invites you, be reserved, and he will invite you more insistently.
verses.comment: Learning wisdom leads to spiritual prudence. Christ urges vigilance and watchfulness—key virtues for all believers (cf. Mark 13:33).

verses.text: When you are invited, withdraw, and do not put yourself forward, so that you are not rejected. Do not push yourself, or you may be turned away.
verses.comment: Jesus echoes this wisdom in Luke 14:8-10, calling his disciples to humility. True greatness comes from self-abasement and waiting for God to exalt us.

verses.text: Do not be assertive lest you be rejected, and do not stand far off lest you be forgotten.
verses.comment: Finding the virtuous mean between pride and self-neglect is a hallmark of wisdom. God sees the humble heart.

verses.text: Do not aspire to be seated with rulers; and do not sit at the table with the great, lest you speak much and are reproached, and you are not remembered for your wisdom.
verses.comment: Humility in social situations is elevated by Jesus as the virtue of true leadership (Luke 22:26). Wisdom acts in silence and service.

verses.text: Let your words be short, in the presence of those in power; for it is not fitting to repeat yourself, nor to act as if you know more than others.
verses.comment: Silence and discretion are marks of wisdom. In the New Testament, James counsels being slow to speak (James 1:19).

verses.text: Every living creature loves its own kind, and every man loves his neighbor.
verses.comment: Here is a natural law principle, fulfilled and elevated by Jesus in the commandment to love one another (John 13:34).

verses.text: All flesh associates with its own kind, and people cling to those like themselves.
verses.comment: Friendship based on shared values and nature reflects God’s design for communion—pointing to the Church as a place of true unity through Christ.

verses.text: What fellowship can the wolf have with the lamb? Just so, the sinner with the godly.
verses.comment: Echoes of the messianic prophecy in Isa. 11:6, where the wolf will dwell with the lamb, showing Christ’s power to reconcile all things.

verses.text: What peace can there be between the hyena and the dog? So also, what peace between the rich and the poor?
verses.comment: Earthly distinctions serve to remind us that only in the kingdom of God are these divides truly overcome (cf. Gal. 3:28).

verses.text: As the wild donkeys are the prey of lions in the wilderness, so the poor are the pasture of the rich.
verses.comment: The Psalmist laments the oppression of the poor by the wicked; divine justice is eventual and complete.

verses.text: Humility is detestable to the proud, just as the poor are detestable to the rich.
verses.comment: Those who are proud cannot bear the humble—Jesus' parable of the rich man and Lazarus (Luke 16) illustrates these spiritual realities.

verses.text: When a rich man stumbles, he is supported by friends; but when a poor man falls, even his friends push him away.
verses.comment: Worldly standards often favor the powerful. This calls Christians to practice true charity and not to show partiality (cf. James 2:1-5).

verses.text: If a rich man speaks, everyone listens and praises his words; if the poor man speaks, they say, 'Who is this?' If he stumbles, they push him down even more.
verses.comment: Earthly status often overrides truth, but wisdom (like Christ, who was rejected by men) is ultimately vindicated (cf. 1 Cor. 1:27-29).

verses.text: Wealth is good if it is free from sin; and poverty is called evil in the mouth of the ungodly.
verses.comment: Material wealth is neutral, but must be ordered toward righteousness (cf. Matt. 6:19-21). Christ blessed the poor and called his followers to generosity.

verses.text: A person's heart changes their face, either for good or for evil.
verses.comment: The inner disposition affects outward appearances. Jesus teaches about the eye as the lamp of the body, emphasizing purity of heart.

verses.text: The heart changes the countenance, either for good or for evil.
verses.comment: It is the overflow of the heart that reveals a person’s true self (cf. Luke 6:45). Little actions matter in spiritual growth.

verses.text: The sign of a happy heart is a cheerful face, but to devise proverbs requires painful thinking.
verses.comment: This is wisdom’s call to mortification and self-discipline, echoed throughout both Testaments as foundational for the pursuit of holiness.
